Cangzhou is a prefecture-level city located in eastern Hebei province, China. As of the 2010 census, its built-up area had a population of 1,205,814, while the total population of the prefecture-level administrative unit was 7,134,062. The city is situated approximately 100 km from Tianjin and 150 km from Beijing. Cangzhou was founded during the Southern and Northern Dynasties period (420–589 CE) and consists of 2 districts, 4 county-level cities, 9 counties, and 1 autonomous county.

Cangzhou is characterized as a heavily industrial city, but it also includes significant agricultural areas, known for producing Chinese jujubes and Tianjin Ya Pears. The North China Oil Field is located within its jurisdiction, and the city features a large fishing port and the coal-exporting Huanghua Harbour. It borders Hengshui to the southwest, Baoding to the west, and Langfang to the north, and is near the coast of the Bohai Sea.
